title: 109_s2380
content: The Act titled "U.S. National Security Protection Act of 2006" establishes the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) and defines the term "intelligence community" as per the National Security Act of 1947. The U.S. National Security Protection Act of 2006 establishes the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). The Director of National Intelligence and the Director of Central Intelligence are members, while the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense serve as vice chairs. A Subcommittee on Intelligence, chaired by the Director of National Intelligence, is comprised of the heads of each member of the intelligence community. SEC. 4. Subcommittee review of CFIUS investigations. Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include an Intelligence Subcommittee review process for proposed mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. The Subcommittee on Intelligence of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States will review information and provide comments before and after investigations are conducted. The Subcommittee on Intelligence of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States will review and comment on investigations conducted by the President or CFIUS regarding proposed mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. SEC. 5 amends the Defense Production Act to include critical infrastructure in national security considerations. SEC. 6 addresses certification of national security determinations. The text chunk discusses the process for making a final determination that an investigation is not required for a merger, acquisition, or takeover. This determination can be made by the President or the Secretary of the Treasury with the concurrence of the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense. The President or CFIUS designee must certify in writing that an investigation is not needed for a merger, acquisition, or takeover under subsection (a). This certification cannot be delegated to any person. The President or CFIUS designee must certify in writing that an investigation is not required for a merger, acquisition, or takeover. If there is disagreement among the chair and vice chairs of CFIUS, the President will make the final determination. SEC. 7. MANDATORY SUBMISSION OF INFORMATION. Section 721(c) of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to require persons controlled by or acting on behalf of a foreign government to notify the President of any proposed merger, acquisition, or takeover of US critical infrastructure. The President's designee must be notified of any proposed transaction involving US critical infrastructure, with confidentiality of information ensured. SEC. 8. NOTICES OF REVIEWS AND INVESTIGATIONS AND QUARTERLY REPORTS REQUIRED. Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to include requirements for notifying Congress about proposed mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers and submitting quarterly reports on such activities. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to require notifying Congress about mergers, acquisitions, and takeovers, with quarterly reports to be submitted on these activities. Reports may be unclassified with the option of including a classified annex. The Defense Production Act of 1950 now designates the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) as the President's designee for overseeing mergers, acquisitions, and takeovers, as per an amendment to Section 721.
